hints.content:
Doubling a number is the same as multiplying by $2$.  

Is multiplying a number, $n$, by $8$ equivalent to multiplying by $4$ and $2$?

$n\times8 \stackrel{?}{=}n \times 4 \times 2$

Let's use the table to check.

$n$ | $n\times 8$ | $n\times 4$| $(n \times 4) \times 2 \stackrel{?}{=} n \times 8$
-: |-: |-: |-: |
$1$ | $8$ | $4$ | $4 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 8$
$2$ | $16$ | $8$ | $8 \times2\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 16$
$3$ | $24$ | $12$ | $12 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 24$
$4$ | $32$ | $16$ | $16 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 32$
$5$ | $40$ | $20$ | $20 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 40$
$6$ | $48$ | $24$ | $24 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 48$
$7$ | $56$ | $28$ | $28 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 56$
$8$ | $64$ | $32$ | $32 \times2\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 64$
$9$ | $72$ | $36$ | $36 \times2 \stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 72$
$10$ | $80$ | $40$ | $40\times2\stackrel{\checkmark}{=} 80$

For all of the factors in the table, the statement is true.

Does this work for any number? 

$\begin{align}
n \times 8 &\stackrel{?}=n \times 4 \times 2 \\\\
n \times 8 &\stackrel{?}=n \times (4 \times 2) \\\\
n \times 8&\stackrel{\checkmark}= n \times8
\end{align}$

Yes, the statement is **always** true.
When we multiply by $8$, we *always* get double the number we would get when we multiply by $4$.
